vsfKrFJYwmiQeeqS6rqiOA.text: Lovely place to sit down for some coffee with a tart. The lemon tart is to die for. I've heard the lunch is pretty decent as well. The service is pretty good as well.

yoFhegJQyeITKqlwpadVLA.text: Great place for an afternoon snack. I had a hot chocolate and a caramel shortbread which was amazing! They have outside tables so you can enjoy your hot drink and still watch people passing by. It's a great way to catch your breath and rest a little in between the ups and downs of Edinburgh! For the great location, the prices are okay.

b14CWC81_pE8xvOvOHnITQ.text: Lovely little cafe that was a welcome respite from the drizzle and cold. Although they were busy, they seated 5 of us within about 5 minutes, and took our order quickly. My coffee was good, and I had a lovely scone with cream and jam. Also pinched one of Lauren's haggis balls, which was lovely, with a good amount of pepper. Staff were great, and the cafe had a nice atmosphere.

DpuadrIiCkdrX8agkk1E3g.text: The Southern Cross cafe is a contemporary eaterie where you can get everything from panini's to haggis as a main!   I must say, my eyes almost popped out my head when I saw the price of said panini's - some of them were over a fiver! But they looked tasty, were well made and this seems to be the standard charge for any food business near the Royal Mile.  There's quite a lot of space to stretch out inside, and I like the shape of the restaurant since it's windy, abstract and off kilter. There are some intimate tables tucked away in cosy corners and enough space for a sneaky bit of people watching towards the front door.  As for the food, it ranges from Italian pasta options to Mediterranean fillings for sandwiches. As well as fulfilling your quota of carby goodness, there are also haggis options, including an appetizer pot for 3.50! This is great for the adventurous tourist or the Scottish fan of this spicy snack.  So although I almost grudged paying 2.40 for a hot chocolate, I was too swayed by the quality of this lovely little den to care about the cost.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

LL3DvYrSWJxTmWxzvaVdIA.text: Such a lovely wee spot. The staff were beyond lovely, the food was decent, and there was a great vibe about the place.

THMb_C9eSwZKha913bEfAw.text: Perfect for hanging out and wasting time with free wifi. Solid coffee, but only average food. I wouldn't necessarily seek this place out at lunch, but if I'm heading in or out of Edinburgh it's a great place to set up shop for a few hours.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Large latte
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Panini + soup of the day
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Street view from the outdoor patio

48rAgV3ONZIvY_MyxJBAHQ.text: The first cafe I ever went to - and I am still coming back, even to this day.  If that isnt enough detail for you, let me explain.  The food is excellent - and, more importantly, there is a huge selection. Yes, the prices are a bit on the steep side, but what do you expect from a place so close to the royal mile?  My favourate thing has to be the outside seating however, there is nothing better than sitting outside with a coffee, a tuna melt panini (in my opinion the best they do here) and watching the world go by.   Splended.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

Ir7V7r98qx0716F8C3LKlw.text: How did I even end up here!?!?! I have not got a clue, but I sat for a good hour or so and thought it was perfectly average.......  The selection is much what I expected, soup, all day breakfasts, paninis, burgers, scampi and such like! I ended up having a coffee and taking advantage of the free wifi. Coffee was alright, not the worst I have had, but not the best.  I then decided to have the very tempting sounding Sweet Potato and Chorizo soup. What a let down it was. I do not know if it is a Scottish thing, or an Islander thing but I want to be able to stick wallpaper up with my soup! This was a very orange looking dishwater. It did not taste of much..... and more to the point no chunks of sweet potato.... or chorizo!?!?! I ate it all but was not very satisfied at all.   So basically I would maybe go back, but might avoid the soup next time just incase!

tmQJPeNzTFUTgckj-nTGpw.text: Cute place but sub-par service and average food. Ordered the soup and sandwich combo and was told that they were out of the ciabatta bread so they would put it on a wrap. This resulted in a very small, quesadilla-like sandwich which should have been much cheaper based on the bread swap. We were excited to try the soup of the day which was potato leek, but were disappointed that our sandwiches came with tomato soup (which was far too sweet) and wish they had told us they were out of the soup before we ordered. Overall we felt that we could have gotten a tastier and more substantial meal for far cheaper.

blWUtRnvWI_kCColMd5w1g.text: I'm clearly not around the Royal Mile and Cockburn Street enough as I had never noticed this cafe before! Myself and a friend went in to escape the bitterly cold weather. We were shown to a table in the back as we wanted to be as far away from the door and the cold as possible. I just had a scone and hot chocolate which were fine, but my friend had quesadillas which looked really appetising and she said it tasted really good. I think I'll need to go back to try out some other food on the menu.

aKeq7cju94mOL-DA4D-lzQ.text: Wonderfully friendly service and a pleasant place to sit for a bit with a cup.  We ordered cappuccinos which were expertly made by the man in charge.  Best coffee we had over two weeks in Great Britain.  We went back to try the food while waiting for our train out of Edinburgh, though, and it didn't hold up to the atmosphere or the coffee.  Still, I'd recommend Southern Cross Cafe over any of the options available in the train station!

qqWbX4JJCTgqN9SWLSaEow.text: My lunch was exactly what my encroaching cold craved. Thank you so much for the delicious big bowl of parsnip soup and the brie pannini on bread that was fresh rustic perfection!

NlcH1n9l_95IxIVhZddqDg.text: Veggie haggis?!?!?!  But oh so glad that I dared, it was really, really good!  This cafe is situated right off of Princes Street, complete with stone face exterior and is cozy inside.  Granted, the cups of coffee are tiny, but the breakfast special can't be beat.    I visited a couple of years ago, and the breakfast was priced well for a full Scottish breakfast, with choice of standard haggis, or veggie haggis.   The veggie version was fantabulous!  Spices of bergamont and lavender permeated through this soy based scoop of tastiness, I would love to go back to Edinburgh (again, I do love this city), and stop by here again for breakfast.  Tasty, tasty!

uUkTpvBdk4QJpY_ObgEbXQ.text: Being linked to a backpackers hostel, you'd expect this place to be a bit shabby round the edges, serving cheap food to hungry tourists you want to spend as little as possible.  You'd be wrong.  I'd say it's somewhere between a cafe and a bistro, as it's licensed to serve alcohol and it's open until around midnight. And the quality's so much higher than you'd expect - both the service and the actual food itself. I went with a friend recently, and we managed to nab ourselves one of the half dozen or so outdoor tables which meant we had prime people-watching range all over Cockburn Street and the adjacent Hunter Square.  We only had coffees, but the food menu did have some tasty-looking things on it that caught my eye, and I'll be heading back here soon for a spot of lunch to give it a whirl. It's never going to win any awards for offering the best value for money of all the eateries in Edinburgh, but don't let that put you off.

g024ObGdwipIuobYck9jFg.text: I actually thought the Southern Cross Cafe was some sort of hostel when I walked up and saw the crowd of young backpackers sitting outside munching toasties and swigging from big mugs of tea. Fancying a bit of that myself, I tottered in and had a look at the very reasonable and tasty looking menu.  I left a few minutes later with some juice and a cheese toastie which I didn't think was too expensive  for the location of the cafe. The queue was massive as I pushed past loads of hungry folk, old and young this time, and I found myself wondering what this cafe had to pull in the punters like it did. Taking a bite of my toastie, which was hotter than the sun on the inside (be warned!), I realised that there really is nothing like a bit of home cooked comforts, especially if you're travelling and need to be perked up with a toasted sandwich like your granny makes.   Great wee caff, well worth a visit but don't expect to get a seat outside!

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

6L4jRvu4vHQGzupRLT4fEA.text: Cute and cosey. Friendly staff with great coffee and yummies!  My husband and I stopped in after a busy day of sightseeing and we're glad we did.

U79ZUf0f-OYgSQwUtc1h7Q.text: Coffee.  I. Need.  Coffee.  That's why I stopped in.  Sure I could've walked a little further to the Starbucks at the top of the road, but this place caught my eye.  Inside is really nice and the staff were really friendly, but not in the "it is too early in the morning to every be that peppy" sort of friendly.  They let you add your own milk to your coffee and I ended up getting a massive brownie to take away, you know, for a little snack later.  The brownie was delicious ;)

h0p8aUsfYiV-VcDDzzaALQ.text: Not exactly sure what's going on here.  While the food and service were decent (not great), I was kind of expecting a bargain given its hostel roots.  Alas... I opted for a latte, the Croque Madame and an order of pancakes thinking that would fill my belly nicely.  You've heard of silver dollar pancakes?  These were more like 50 pancakes.  Of course they COST 3.95, which at current exchange rates come out to about $7.  For three TINY pancakes.  And I guess I'm still learning the ins and outs of food here in the UK -- the syrup was (I think) just honey, and not enough to cover three JFK's worth of batter.  Oh well -- the servers were friendly and the place was hopping for an early morning, I'd just rather not drop 10 for a very average breakfast.  Call me cheap, or maybe just American...

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. $16 worth of food?

j7dBv3qBD2xSKnfZ6SVLag.text: Hit the spot. I popped in here during a rushed day, having missed lunch I asked if they did something like a cheeseburger. What I got was a substantial and very tasty burger and chips (not fries!!) and coffee so nice I suspect it couldn't be decaf. Service was very good too. Pricewise what I paid was about twice the price of a McDonalds meal but I would much rather have SX burger than two big macs! Just off the Royal Mile and probable better for it.

GAQFieYfJFGCiEEJLBi-6Q.text: Nice cafe with great food. The coffee is "normal" (nothing special) and the staff is a little bit confused ;) But I would visit it again!

dHjFjbPCRGS_SYopkPvO9A.text: Southern Cross is situated just around the corner from the Royal Mile, nestled in between numerous cute cafes and gift shops.  One quick peek of the menu from outside was all it took to lure me in. I was only after a light bite so when Chicken & Cheddar Quesadillas with Fresh Salad jumped out at me, it was a done deal.   I opted for a seat in the back room, which was dimly lit, with colourful, quirky art on the walls and Vampire Weekend playing on the music system.   It took a few minutes for someone to come over and ask what I wanted to order but when they did, they were smiley and polite so I forgave them instantly.   The food wasn't anything amazing but then I wasn't really expecting Michelin Star cuisine from a small cafe. It could have been a little more flavoursome though. A few herbs / spices would have helped but it's not the end of the world.   I washed it down with a glass of Fentiman's Ginger Beer then settled the bill - 7.90, which I suppose isn't too bad.   Next time I'm in Edinburgh (there WILL be a next time), I don't think I'll go here again as there are sooooo many other cute cafes to choose from, but it certainly did its job in ensuring I had a good feed and watering ahead of my long and tedious journey back to Manc Land.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Not the best photo but here&#39;s the quesadillas and salad I ordered
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. View from the back room

WWRuVxiF7P83ZvQSa4vRug.text: Good place to have breakfast. The price is fair. You can have breakfast here under 10 pounds. free wi-fi.  The service is good. The staff are friendly. I had a hot chocolate and it was amazing. For my breakfast, I had Eggs Florentine which was also good. My friend had Blueberry Stackers which was fine. I recommend this place to have breakfast in.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Blueberry Stackers. They&#39;re fine but not the best.
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Eggs Florentine with extra mushroom. Fair price under £10.
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. This hot chocolate is amazing.

B-vS4uwOGacNtTqOJZSohQ.text: If you want a solid breakfast near the tourist centre of Edinburgh but away from the crowds, this is the place! Brandon A. and I enjoyed breakfast here so much, we went back again the next day. We were very lucky to get a table without waiting, as even on weekday mornings the place filled up quickly!  Southern Cross Cafe, situated on the pleasant Cockburn Street (right off the Royal Mile) makes a mean breakfast and a fantastic (strong) cup of coffee. The pancakes are amazing (and caramelized!), poached eggs are perfectly poached, nice big croissants, lovely tattie scones... great start the the day.   Very reasonably priced (you can easily eat here for under 10), with options on the menu to suit every appetite. Decor is fun (kind of constellation-night sky themed, which makes sense considering the cafe's name) plenty of seating, friendly staff.

Dz6ycmupmiRjJcaE3IwI-A.text: We popped in here for a quite bite to eat, hot drink and rest whilst it was raining.  It was quite busy which made for a nice atmosphere and they managed to squeeze our group of five in after a short wait.  Whilst everyone else had coffees and tasty looking scones and jam (but with squirty cream rather than clotted!), I indulged in haggis bon bons!  They were deep fried little balls of haggis accompanied by a mustard mayo. They were not only really yummy but also a great way to sample haggis whilst in Bonny Scotland!  Ps. The signs downstairs and in the toilets are fantastic! Pop down and make your favourite your motto for the week!

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Haggis bon bons in Bonny Scotland

phXeArB00lTrNx3R7pcMSg.text: Slightly better than average place with free wi-fi.  I don't exactly love it, there's nothing unique about it and something about the atmosphere wasn't totally comfortable, but there's nothing really wrong with the place. As other reviewers have said, the service is variable, usually fine, but sometimes I don't know, stern maybe?  There is lots of natural light despite being in perpetually balmy Scotland. I've been twice now and got breakfast both times (their breakfast menu ends at lunch time, but they do a full or full vegetarian till later in the day). The vegetarian haggis is not really what I imagine hangs to be. Usually with vegetarian, it is cooked like the regular but is just slightly smoother as it doesn't have those bits in (the suet I think), but the Southern Cross version seemed like basically kidney beans and barley mixed together, so  texture wise it was like chunky mashed potatoes. Anyway, it was alright as it's own thing, but I wouldn't call it veg haggis.   The first time I went, my friend was visiting and tried (real) haggis for the first time and said it was surprisingly good. I'm not sure if this is worth anything because he tends to only eat things that don't require utensils, and he ordered it as a challenge, expecting a monstrosity of organ parts, but still. It is an okay place to bring people if they want to try haggis cheap as there are filled rolls and what we got which were the bon bons. Not the best in the area, but not a commitment either if they don't like it.  Prices are as expected, and it's a convenient location as it's by the train and just off the Royal Mile. You could do worse, but I probably won't bother going back.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Veg Breakfast £6.95

UYliAKtcVEum08uGKzCUrg.text: Southern Cross is the first place I think of for a quickish lunch with a friend before they have to catch the train. Just a little less than halfway down Cockburn Street, which winds colourfully toward the Market Street entrance to the station, it's ideally located and, inside, bigger than it looks.  I've been here a couple of times; on this most recent visit, I opted for the smoked salmon toast with cream cheese. It was really good, but - and I can't believe this is actually a criticism! - too much salmon. I are well over three quarters of it but by the time the toast and cheese were all gone, it began to be a little sickly just downing the salmon.  They have lots of cakes and things which (amazingly) I've not tried yet, but they look good. Be aware that they also will not split a bill for you. That seems totally weird to me; I understand it during the high visitor volumes of August since it can slow proceedings but on a regular day I don't see why they'd simply refuse...  Service is also variable. The first time I came, I had a delightfully charming young man who admired my brooch. This most recent time, the young lady was civil, but slightly curt. Nonetheless, the three of us got fed amply and had a drink each, and the bill came to 26, which really isn't bad in the Mile area.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

w9grWi7GUbK6QED4PzoF8Q.text: Best on Ground: Blueberry pancakes with Golden Syrup and Cream. Closely followed by the Gentleman's favourite - Eggs Benedict.  Coffee: Best I've had in Scotland.  Staff: Friendly, attentive and always happy to converse. The kind of staff a hospitality business owner can trust to make their place stand out.  Atmosphere: Casual, friendly and relaxing with nice tunes.  A five star rating for the best coffee shop I've been to in Europe!

e8bENkTMQ0sZZOUeay_wOQ.text: Good place to go for breakfast, they even did gluten free bread. They are very busy so be prepared to wait during peak times. I found upstairs warm but my companion didn't. My friend likes her breakfast well done and they did a fabulous job. I had poached egg, bacon and gluten free bread and it was well cooked. My friend had a full Scottish breakfast and she ate it all.   Great place for breakfast

7Py2bvzokXHnuA_EQ34_NA.text: Stumbled on this place and had a delightfully surprising lunch (falafel burger was tasty, though the fries were way over-salted). Ask for a side of goat cheese and, by American standards, you get nearly a wheel for the price of a wedge - terrific addition! I liked this place so much for lunch that I came back later in my trip for breakfast! (Of course, it didn't hurt that it was one of the few places open for breakfast on a Sunday, at an earlier hour.)

mo73OMvvNWoin2VW3LIlrQ.text: Just had a Big Belter breakfast and it was amazing!!  Really friendly staff, great food and great atmosphere.   The cakes look amazing as welll!!  If you're in Edinburgh come here!

tr96PyBDwguvuNFwfWxoTQ.text: Popped in here for a late lunch while in Edinburgh for a day out. We didn't plan to come in here but decided that the exterior looked really quirky so decided to try!   As you enter it looks like your usual coffee shop - some seating areas and a large blackboard over the till area with your menu and drinks - so there I was waiting to order at the till as you do. But turns out it's an actual restaurant which was a surprise to us as we were looking for something quick. But we decided to just stay as we were just starving!   We were taken to the upstairs level of the restaurant, which was nice as a lot of the decor and flooring was wooden so it felt a bit like you were in a tree house..   The staff and food was lovely, however it is probably on the pricey side considering it was a sort of coffee shop with a restaurant priced menu.   Overall was a good experience, will recommend :)

EP_5wuUDJzD1OM1KV7Pl7g.text: So cute and quirky the staff are super nice and the service was quick. Love that they have free wifi! It's a great place to do homework!

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Flat White
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Goat Cheese Salad

KdOjS5NFGQMnxXiRDPdQjQ.text: Limited choices for breakfast, but that's okay because what they had was what I wanted. I was tempted to go for the Scottish Breakfast or the Big Belter, but my brain overruled as I had a busy day ahead. I settled for the Croque Madame, which was kind of like two pressed ham and cheese sandwiches with a fried egg on top. Not too much fat and plenty of energy for a walking tour of Edinburgh. Delicious.  I was going to have just the one cup of coffee but ended up having a second because it was just that good. For two large coffees and the sandwich, still less than 10.  Free wi-fi was easy to access, after I got the password from the staff.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Menu on the wall
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Croque Madame
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Good coffee!

Nm84UhMcQBPOoqi8Y5p87w.text: Nice...I just wish the food was better  We dropped in a few days ago for an afternoon pick-me-up and am happy to report they have nice staff, a great location, and some tasty coffee. But, we had a coconut/raspberry tart that was sweet but dry and tasteless, a lemon tart that was way too gelatinous and insufficiently lemon-y and a hazelnut/chocolate thang that while having a better consistency than the first two also suffered from a lack of flavor.

2mhPjA_dp1__quBqbRvyFg.text: Really nice workers who are super busy but the food is not good and it takes over 30min to get your order

AV8c5Ntlx_NvUrp7nT9YgQ.text: Food was edible, service lackluster. My wife's pasta of the day was tasty but my "Spicy couscous salad" was as bland as bland can be. Nary a spice to be found. Despite ordering a salad and special of the day it took 50 minutes from ordering to get our food.

ZBN514FDNS72E7DpzvHXDg.text: Such a lovely little cafe, friendly staff and great food! 10/10 will definitely go back.

xpM0YmeFmRnrXEgSXEl0jQ.text: Came here for breakfast because if you stay at Edinburgh Backpackers you get a discount and it was well worth it. Just under 4 pounds for a full breakfast with vegetarian haggis (made of lentils, I think they only call it haggis because it looks the same) that was delicious. I was told it was better than the real haggis my friend tried the night before. Really cute interior and I would definitely have come back for lunch if I was staying in Edinburgh longer, especially to try the soup special they had that day--spicy carrot!

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

allyPsjcFqjkOXh0628sGw.text: The haggis Scottish breakfast doesn't disappoint. Ridiculously busy for weekend brunch but very hospitable service nonetheless. Modern cafe + brunch place that is appropriate for all occasions.

OaJF1LWH6qxDgQpI2YwqqA.text: Among the cobblestones and stonework of Old Town Edinburgh, the Southern Cross Cafe offers a more modern interior, while still serving traditional classics. Make the hike up the narrow Fleshmarket Close to Cockburn Street from Market Street below, and sit down for your morning coffee.   My friend and I were in for breakfast, and they have many well priced options. I was naturally drawn to the full Scottish breakfast, but then indulged in the Double Belter, which was the same thing, just more prodigious. Two eggs, sausage, bacon, potatoes, mushrooms, beans, tomato - the works. And with coffee, it only ran me about 9. My companion had a more modest egg sandwich, which looked delightful. The Southern Cross is highly recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The Double Belter
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The Southern Cross Cafe

QnkPdtCygpQF2Bfi7wuJVg.text: Perfect way to start your day in Edinburgh. Fast WiFi, good food and great service and on a perfect location.

-Jd-a0WJw5CTihKatsTTAQ.text: A lovely cafe next to the royal mile. The chains of light, signs and  extraordinary furniture create a great atmosphere. Really friendly staff, fantastic cappucchino and cafe and lovingly arranged breakfast. The pancakes and joghurt with fruits are awesome! I recommend it to everyone!

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

HzYYwYpXe9qCs39cN3vvpQ.text: Good breakfast place. We ate here twice while in Edinburgh and the food was good and the service was excellent. I would definitely recommend.

aL8GB-gEJaJNL5qGvtm6Vg.text: They've got everything I want a full coffee bar and a great Scottish Breakfast menu I've only been to Scotland once though visited this place three times while I was there, as crazy as it was at the Fringe festival they made sure we felt welcome and mad us look forward to our next visit. Ps here is a link for the owner beautiesltd.com/category...

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

kEUgy2ZrA7aTPpXfe41drA.text: The food was fresh and very tasty! I got the eggs Benedict and my hubs got the eggs royal (it had smoked salmon). We both loved it.   Their sauce is very well made.

Rh2NkYJTOrmBckB34rOf4A.text: We came here by a suggestion from a local to try the haggis, and it didn't disappoint!  I got the full Scottish breakfast, which was delicious and my sister ordered an equally tasty goat cheese salad.    The interior of the restaurant was quite charming and the people sincerely asked us if the food was good and if everything was alright - an act I really appreciate in restaurants.  The service was only a little slow with getting our check and the water we ordered never came, but we went during a busy lunch hour so it's understandable.   Overall, really enjoyed the food and the atmosphere here!  They also have free wifi, which is always a blessing if you don't have cellular service in Scotland.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Full English breakfast (haggis is on the side dish) and goat cheese salad.

ZlAPn0e2uUdQbPHTuoxD1A.text: I only had one weekend in Edinburgh, so having a really good full Scottish breakfast was important. Looking through Yelp and TripAdvisor, we found the Southern Cross Cafe that had consistently good reviews and had a full Scottish and a veggie full Scottish (!!). We arrived just before they stopped serving breakfast (11:30am) and the waitress was so lovely and told us she'd get our orders in quickly so we didn't miss out. I ordered the veggie Scottish and my boyfriend had the Belt Buster (a full Scottish plus extra eggs, hash brown, meat etc). My veggie breakfast was really good. I had two eggs, a hash brown, veggie haggis (made of lentils, oats and some other things- I asked), toast, beans, mushrooms, tomato and a potato pancake thing. It was so nice to have such a good option as a veggie and I really enjoyed trying "haggis" for the first time. My boyfriend's breakfast was massive with everything I had plus sausage and bacon and real haggis. It doesn't sound like much more food on the menu, but it was massive. Probably better to order the normal size and get something afterwards if you're still hungry. I also had a latte with my breakfast, which was good, as was my boyfriend's filter coffee.   Overall, a great way to have started our weekend in Edinburgh with good food and nice service. Overall we paid around 25 or so (veggie breakfast is about 10, belt buster 12-13)

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Veggie breakfast and belt buster

fP9dMwh3dC2tACuIXGMXJA.text: FOOD 2//SERVICE 4// AMBIANCE 3  I was very diappointed by the quality of coffee and scone at this location. The ambiance is nice and cozy ( but definitely a bigger cafe) and the service was super duper pleasant but the scone was tasteless and just so bland. The cappuccino I got was aesthetically pleasing but the espresso was weak and it was too milky/watered down.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Scone &amp; cappuccino

LJcpLC0tLIftloLukyAmog.text: Charming breakfast place with big old stone walls, which is part of what I love about old town Edinburgh.    Great young staff.  Very friendly and service was excellent.  Had the eggs benedict which were simply yummy.     I'll definitely be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

MrMDvDvV2DnFcN4fW83lHw.text: We came here a few times over the course of our short trip to Edinburgh. The food was always excellent and the staff was friendly and attentive, even when it was busy.  I got the blueberry stackers on one day, which were delicious though a bit too sweet. I think the outside of the pancakes were caramelized so they outside was extra sweet and crunchy and the inside was soft and chewy. Despite the fact that the sugar content was intense, I finished the whole thing because ultimately it was really tasty and filling.  On another day I got the ham and cheese croissant. I wasn't expecting it to be particularly filling, but I was wrong! Not only was it delicious, I didn't feel the need to eat afterwards for quite a while.  I would recommend this place to travelers and locals alike!

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Stackers!

DAfiK_wQags5kRb32hQBug.text: Best breakfast place we found in Edinburgh. Friendly service with plenty of seating. We never had to wait when we came in here.   I definitely recommend the Scottish breakfast they offer. They have a good selection and decent coffee. I especially like the atmosphere and clean bathrooms this place provides.   The pastries here are very good if you want something smaller.

KsrTtzjo6Ul-DWpheV5MlQ.text: We had a delicious,affordable, filling breakfast, served by a kind young lady.  On this day of snow, inclement weather and many shops closed, we were grateful the staff made it safely to work and were able to provide a tasty meal for us!

cr75_gisGjQoP_Gcx9wLow.text: I went here for brunch while staying at Edinburgh Backpackers next door; the hostel offers a 15% discount at this joint. Let me first say that the inside of this restaurant/cafe is super cute and I love their display of homemade pastries in the window. The menu has plenty of tasty-sounding options.  I liked the food a lot; I had the barbecue chicken wrap, while my girlfriend had the vegetarian breakfast. I had no complaints about either of these dishes, or the coffee.  What I did have a problem with was the service. The girl who greeted and seated us was nice enough, but our waitress was very unfriendly. She could barely muster a "how are you" when we sat down, and seemed completely disinterested in providing a friendly, warm cafe environment. It was difficult to get her attention for tap water, let alone anything else, though she seemed able to pay lots of attention to her boyfriend/partner who also appeared to work there.  It's not a bad place to grab a bite, and the food is yummy enough. Just don't expect great, prompt service or a smile when you come here.

C7P23nJKtu78dVK6-p6qHg.text: Super delicious Scottish meal! Stumbled upon this place after we tried to go to another that was full. Incredible delicious food at a great price-split the The Bug Belter between two people and it was a perfect amount of food! Great Sunday morning breakfast!

NIyclpWlw9v_3rcYrsdmKA.text: Had breakfast here on the last morning in Edinburgh. Overall, everything was A-OK. Nothing to write home about, but it hit the spot. This seems like a great coffee shop with many gluten-full options. Being gluten free, not a wide variety, but a few.

y35y9FqXBy9qLADczPk0-g.text: Words cannot describe my love for this little brunch spot. Three and a half years ago, my family and I visited Edinburgh for the first time and happened upon the Southern Cross Cafe for breakfast our morning. The cute decor, wonderful staff, and amazing food ensured a return visit our second morning - which we almost never do since we usually opt to try new places when we travel.   Fast forward to this year, I went back to Edinburgh with friends. I somehow tracked this place down, and it didn't disappoint. The decor was the same, the food and coffee as delicious. The staff had changed, but they were even friendlier!   Between my two friends and I, we split the Big Belter, not knowing what we were getting ourselves into. Suffice to say, we probably left a third of the plate behind despite stuffing ourselves beyond our limits!   Basically, go!! I'll be spending my mornings here any time I visit this city (:

a6ASUSkun_bkoyrySTNy4w.text: Scones with fresh cream to die for. Scottish smoked salmon delightful. Good cup of tea after an all night flight

tnJkMTLHCc738lqCYu9bHQ.text: Nice wee cafe with seating and a versatile menu featuring classics like eggs benny and the full Scottish. The prices are decent for the area of town and the service was top notch. It's a great spot for breakfast or lunch...they do close at five though so no evening snacks here...

Dk8M16jOQ003vpuXHsbXqQ.text: This is such a cozy breakfast spot. The staff are welcoming and the atmosphere is wonderful. We both got lattes that were delicious and I had an egg sandwich that was wonderful. It was a great spot to tuck into before a full day and we enjoyed ourselves!

MCfyxxLIj2DjS0TAhLF1Jg.text: Nice staff, pleasant setting, amazing home baking. Recommend the almond chocolate cake! We didn't have but someone ordered hot choc and both cream and marshmallows portions were generous! Will be back! :)

nG-H7Ak1Q1yeE-5G9R7Lgw.text: Great little place with good vegetarian options and inexpensive but high quality food

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Vegetarian Scottish breakfast

cryxO_yDMTZCKUpA82TqdA.text: Dropped in after lunch, had the breakfast, wife had the club.  Very good food and generous portions staff was very friendly.  No room for desserts but will drop back by to try those.

5Dxx4Yx236na_EK8dLf3vQ.text: Wow! Love the atmosphere, the food, and the service. We came here yesterday for lunch and loved it. It's just barely off the beaten path of the Royal Mile (whose restaurants are bustling with tourists) and we got a table here lickety-split. We ended up staying for about 2.5 hours and read our Kindles.   We came back for breakfast this morning because lunch was so tasty, and it looks wonderful! Their coffee is delicious! We will definitely return here the next time we visit Edinburgh.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

DCh6drsDaiB1ePMkLcH4oQ.text: Really cute "cottage" feel cafe. Came here for breakfast one morning and it was quiet busy but managed to get a seat. They had tasty coffee and a large menu. I decided on the "Blueberry Stackers" which was three blueberry pancakes with golden syrup and cream for 7.95 - which was a little steep for what you get but was yummy none the less.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Cappuccino
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Interior
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Interior

yQRXpJLk4h_ROaZxvOmBZw.text: The Southern Cross Cafe is a very nice location in the town centre, we had a place on the first floor and had cappuccino and a little lunch.  In the store window a variety of tasty cakes were shown.

WhJ0WaJGOiZs-qc067gALQ.text: Delicious food! It was our first time trying black pudding and haggis and we were not disappointed. Everything was perfectly, exactly as it was described. We hope to visit again on our next trip

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

E_D8eZsKI-_FrGNtwcespA.text: It was great breakfast with great service.  Good selection.

APzTdTJ8VRXDC4hBCRpslw.text: We happened across this cafe after we arrived at our hostel and dropped our bags off. It's a cute cafe, full of tables, and bakery items near the espresso machine. We sat at the window on the stools. I ordered the big belter, which was a step up in size of the Scottish breakfast and added hash browns. I liked all the food, except for black pudding. I will not eat black pudding or anything that contains blood. I guess it's my line in the sand. I didn't care for the service. It wasn't busy, but the server was a bit of a dingbat and didn't take our orders and we had to flag down another server. Also, it's not specified, but we were charged another cup of tea for more water, and another cup of coffee. No refills. Would have been nice to know, since I would have passed up and saved a couple of pounds.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Big belter was way bigger than I expected. Oof.

l-5qDLtuCbeQQqgChTSdXA.text: Just the best coffee shop in Edinburgh.  Servers are totally awesome and friendly. Coffee blend is strong and balanced. Breakfast croissants are delicious, and the walnut and coffee cake divine.

CAbWA9FHJPBIMS_MKGC_Og.text: I grabbed breakfast here during my stay in Edinburgh and it's such a near little cafe. It's much larger inside than it looks from the outside, with three floors of seating available.  Service is fast and friendly and I really liked the Eggs Benedict. Coffee is a bit weak though.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

-TTm0PoC1Tf0naghbQbMOw.text: One of Edinburgh's 'non-traditional' places!  The staff is friendly and you get your ordered food quite quickly. We had two different ciabattas which both were pretty good. The pea&mint soup wasn't my kind of thing but if you like the combination of peas and mint, go ahead. The interior is lovely and stylish but cozy anyway. If you're looking for a nice place besides the Scottish pub Charme, this is a great cafe to go. They also serve beer & cider but you only got a few options to chose from - which is fine.

kkltTmsFo6kxESHcsO1fDQ.text: What a lovely quirky place down Cockburn street off the royal mile. The inside is bigger as it looks as it spans over 3 floors.  The walls and interior is wooden and gives this place a cozy feel especially with the christmas lights hanging from the ceiling. I ordered an Americano and scone with cream and blackberry jam. One of the best scone and cream combination I ever ate. The personell is very friendly and fast service even at busy times. I will be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

Hd_WngrvX6EoN3ayLEyKOQ.text: Southern Cross is a really cute breakfast place in old town. The front window is full of delicious looking cakes and desserts. There is free wifi and the atmosphere is really cool. Inside the cafe there is seating on the lower level, as well as an upper level, so a lot of people can fit into the tiny space. For the price portions were quite generous and filled us up for a day of exploring the city. Absolutely delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

SolTjaa-bwxixj1JIIqR8Q.text: This place was bursting at the seams on the Saturday morning we wandered in here straight off a red-eye flight, which is always a good sign. The Eggs Royale I ordered was absolutely delicious, and my husband loved his Scottish breakfast as well. I was only sad that I didn't have room for one of the amazing looking pastries in the window. The atmosphere was cozy and warm, everything you want in a breakfast spot. My only complaint is that the staff was not very attentive - we stood in the entry awkwardly for quite a while before anyone even acknowledged us, and our plain coffees came out well after we got our food. Still, we would definitely go again.

Nx2Mbix2pUAq7_kitv5e7g.text: Well the decoration is great and comfy but the food... First the tea they served is a tea bag from twining which is far from good The carrot cake was ok but not delicious  I guess it's a good place to rest if you are not looking for good food....

0w018uaRUYgABGEKDsw_6A.text: The Southern Cross cafe is mainly visited by tourists, but I am quite a fan myself. It has good food and friendly staff. I think it has been refurbished recently too as it looked a lot sleeker than it used to today.  After leaving the Apple Store, we decided to come here for breakfast as it was just across Waverley Bridge. We were seated immediately and ordered our food.  The drinks arrived fairly quickly but the food did take about 20 minutes. It was a bit slow although they were quite busy with their breakfast rush. It was worth the wait though as the food was delicious.  I opted for the blueberry pancakes with cream and syrup and they were some of the best that I've had! I am quite the pancake connoisseur, if you didn't know.  Another thing I like about SX is it's central location - up the hill from Princes Street and down the hill from the Royal Mile. Don't bother with the Starbucks up the road. Instead, come here. It is more expensive but it is nicer and has a cute personal touch.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Blueberry pancakes!

A38JRBOmvrptBKhcgR3tVw.text: Delicious breakfast. I started off breakfast with a flat white which was excellent.   I had the full Scottish breakfast. It came with a fried egg which was cooked perfectly, sausage, bacon, mushrooms, tomato, toast, tattie scone and haggis. The whole meal was delicious! I personally am not a fan of haggis, definitely an acquired taste. The meal was filling and wasn't overly expensive. It was about 45 for four people.   When looking for breakfast in Edinburgh, this is a good stop!

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Full Scottish breakfast

auiah953IHaRcXIaHKGSNA.text: We came here based on the Yelp reviews, and were very underwhelmed. The toast was store-bought, the bacon was dry, the haggis was the end of the tube, the egg was fried hard, and the hollandiase sauce had no acidity. The mushrooms and  beans were good, and the inside  was cool, but I wish we'd gone elsewhere.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Underwhelming. Wish we&#39;d gone elsewhere.

xl_0ONny9OGFJMIB0g0DxA.text: Great breakfast conveniently located right in the heart of the Royal Mile. I got a traditional vegetarian Scottish breakfast, with beans, eggs, toast, hashbrowns, mushrooms, tomatoes, and veggie haggis. Honestly, the authentic haggis was much better and surprisingly delicious, so I would recommend getting the traditional breakfast. The ambiance of the cafe is also great, but the top floor is pretty cramped - we had to scoot our chairs uncomfortably close to the table about five times during the meal so the waiter and other customers could get by.

photos.caption: Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Vegetarian Scottish breakfast
Photo of Southern Cross Cafe - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Cappuccino

Q98dmwZkHFPZGCYxbg9Mzg.text: A wonderful little cafe with a small, but well rounded menu.   Staff was mostly warm, but those who were not overly warm were quite busy. I was concerned about the quality of service from some of the other reviews, but it proved not to be True during our stay.   As for food, it was very good. Ordered the Scottish Breakfast and wasn't disappointed. The haggis really was the best thing on the plate. Also did an add on if the salmon and the black pudding and both were also delicious.   The entire family of four ate well, drinks and all totaling 45 before gratuity. As we ate late, this will be a brunch and will definitely hold us over until dinner.
